snippet.textDisplay:
Please note the following caveat placed on many websites, Twitter, Wikipedia, YouTube etc:
Climate change United Nations:
“Climate change refers to long-term shifts in temperatures and weather patterns, mainly caused by human activities, especially the burning of fossil fuels.”

This is at best bias, propaganda, exaggeration or based on deliberate social engineering. Sadly it is based on computer models designed to produce the desired result for those commissioning the prediction.
In reality the statement would seem to be a lie.
May I suggest YOU read the full IPCC Report, which fails to support the claim! May I remind you that for centuries the consensus of scientists were claimed to believe the Earth was flat
& the consensus of scientists & the whole of the Catholic Church agreed the Sun, planets & stars all revolved around our planet!

Before the 1970s The Scientific consensus, as shown by advertising at the time, agreed that smoking tobacco was good for you!
Real science has never been reliable and has always depended on debate, new information & proof!
Remember around 80% of electricity we use is generated by Oil, Gas & other, so called Fossil Fuels & there is no scientific proof that CO2 causes Climate Change OR Global Warming!
Clearly, as Oil & Gas are mainly extracted from between 30 & 35,000ft below ground around the planet and science shows there is zero fossil activity below 16,000 ft. below the surface neither Oil nor Gas are Fossil Fuels!
ATMOSPHERIC CO2 - 01
Our planet has had a changing climate, with periods of warming, cooling & ice ages for 4.6BILLION years.
snippet.textOriginal:
Please note the following caveat placed on many websites, Twitter, Wikipedia, YouTube etc:
Climate change United Nations:
“Climate change refers to long-term shifts in temperatures and weather patterns, mainly caused by human activities, especially the burning of fossil fuels.”

This is at best bias, propaganda, exaggeration or based on deliberate social engineering. Sadly it is based on computer models designed to produce the desired result for those commissioning the prediction.
In reality the statement would seem to be a lie.
May I suggest YOU read the full IPCC Report, which fails to support the claim! May I remind you that for centuries the consensus of scientists were claimed to believe the Earth was flat
& the consensus of scientists & the whole of the Catholic Church agreed the Sun, planets & stars all revolved around our planet!
 
Before the 1970s The Scientific consensus, as shown by advertising at the time, agreed that smoking tobacco was good for you!
Real science has never been reliable and has always depended on debate, new information & proof!
Remember around 80% of electricity we use is generated by Oil, Gas & other, so called Fossil Fuels & there is no scientific proof that CO2 causes Climate Change OR Global Warming!
Clearly, as Oil & Gas are mainly extracted from between 30 & 35,000ft below ground around the planet and science shows there is zero fossil activity below 16,000 ft. below the surface neither Oil nor Gas are Fossil Fuels!
ATMOSPHERIC CO2 - 01
Our planet has had a changing climate, with periods of warming, cooling & ice ages for 4.6BILLION years.

snippet.textDisplay:
I am confused on how you found a "caveat", that is a message from the United Nations, on American-based websites like Youtube or Twitter. In fact I'm confused on where at all you found any place for these when most social medias would not be interested in having some dedicated page to climate change and politics. Already you are off to a horrible start.

Invoking mistakes of the past does not change anything about the present, and is a complete strawman argument. Regardless of their true accuracy, we have no other way to know a more accurate solution. If the scientific community determines there is a certain percentage of CO2 in the air, no amount of work you could possible do is going to trump the data an analytics of thousands of separate sources all reaching on conclusion: That humanity is changing the climate, primarily through fossil fuel emissions. Nothing about this is propaganda, and you haven't even attempted to justify that claim. This is just fact.
Besides, it's ridiculous to act like science was at all the same when we believed the Earth was flat, and that the "scientists" (really just considered philosophers back then) at all reflect on the ones of today. That myth was already being dismantled by the time of the Ancient Greeks.
Yes, the other examples you listed are somewhat more recent, though there's quite a difference between 400 years ago and 50. Regardless, again, blind distrust in science is just paranoia and will get you nowhere. Unless there are somehow more reliable results against them, the current scientific consensus is the most factual interpretation we have. There is no other way for science to be reliable without debate, new info, and proof. How on Earth do you consider that a bad thing?

That brings us to the only at least on topic part of your comment, the IPCC Report and claims that fossil fuels aren't affecting anything. What exactly are you looking at from the IPCC Report? I assume you mean the sixth assessment report, for 2022. Considering the full thing is 3068 pages, and you've failed to demonstrate any logical argument so far, I highly doubt you've read the whole thing, so do me a favor and actually provide some reasoning here, because I'm certainly not reading the whole thing. I will say though, some quick poking around the site and reports are telling me that uh... yeah man-made climate change is still definitely a thing.

Also I find it hypocritical that you claim science is unreliable, but then also invoke "science" saying that there is no fossil fuel activity below 16k feet as proof of... something... honestly what does that even mean? Yes no one's pumping fumes into the air from miles up, that doesn't change the fact that gas we spew into our atmosphere mixes into our atmosphere. You didn't even try to provide a source for this. Everything ok up in that brain of yours?

Finally, to address that worn out non-argument you tacked onto the end, yes, the Earth indeed has a natural heating and cooling cycle. What you've failed to understand is that said cycle takes a full 100 thousand years for each rotation. The cycle does not heat up the Earth as fast as has been measured over the past couple of centuries. Scientists have already taken into account that cycle, they're just determined that humanity is heating the Earth up faster than is natural.

snippet.textDisplay:
This was an amazing video, but I have one request to make: please don't hype up carbon capture. Although it's a really good thing that carbon capture is getting plenty of R&D, since it may serve as a tool for us to reverse the centuries-long damage done to our planet in the future, it is still a very expensive and primitive technology, it doesn't reduce other GHG emissions than carbon, and is oftentimes utilised in an extremely counterproductive way: The coal industry, for instance, is using carbon capture as a way to re-invent coal power generation into something they call "clean coal". Which is nothing short of greenwashing. Clean coal is not actually clean in the slightest, and the effect of carbon capture technologies on the GHG emissions of coal power plants is usually very negligible. In that way, carbon capture is used as a way to maintain the status quo, just as electric cars in a car-centric society are.

But we also have countries like Iceland - THE world-leader in renewable energy generation - deploying a whole lot of carbon capture in an attempt to cancel out their carbon emissions. Which is certainly well-intentioned, but we have to keep in mind that GHG emissions is a global issue, not a domestic one. If your own country has already used all the bang-for-your-buck solutions to minimise carbon emissions, it shouldn't start resorting to expensive gimmicks (which carbon capture currently is) to reduce its own emissions further - it should instead start looking abroad. We still have countries that generate most of their energy from coal and natural gas, so invest into expanding renewable energy in those countries while progressively dismantling coal/oil/gas infrastructure. That way, you can reduce much more GHG emissions for the same amount of money. That's only energy generation, you could also contribute in other ways by investing into other countries: upgrades pertaining to industries, waste management, and public transit, to name a few. By treating this like a global issue, we can make the transition much faster and cheaper.

snippet.textDisplay: What about entropy? All life can be considered as systems that reduce their own entropy, but the total entropy always increases (entropy is intimately related to heat, mind you). This means that to create order you must spend a higher amount of "destruction". Bacteria will destroy the chemical bonds in sugars to keep alive and divide, turning on a fridge or AC will heat the environment, tidying up your room burns calories... Humans create order much beyond their own physiology and that's the cause of global warming. Obviously finding better sources of fuel can help slow down the destruction (if we hadn't progressed past burning trees we would be entirely f*cked by now) but reverting climate change seems absolutely impossible to me.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Artemiy Brukhno
Ah yes, I wondered when you'd roll out the 'argumentum ad personam' and 'argumentum ad populum' line and there you have it.

Your side of the argument have a theory, which by definition has never been proven. So in fact, the burden of proof is on you.

If not, then anyone could come up with a theory and then have public policy change because of it.

You didn't look at ALL the things that trap heat on earth and then look at the increase in 'greenhouse' gases relative to that. You just look at the increase in those gases in isolation.

Look at the land and the oceans and the clouds and then look at the greenhouse gases. Also factor in the fact that the greenhouse gases don't form anywhere near a contiguous layer and the heating effect of them is miniscule.

The analogies I come up with are about trapping heat – therefore relevant - and they show a pattern which is if I want to trap a significant amount of heat (an amount that I can feel the difference), then the something I use needs to be significant relative to the body I’m trapping heat for and it needs to be contiguous or near contiguous – each and everytime. Neither of these things apply to the greenhouse gases.

Look at the land and the oceans and the clouds and then look at the greenhouse gases.  Also factor in the fact that the greenhouse gases don't form anywhere near a contiguous layer and the heating effect of them is miniscule.

The analogies I come up with are about trapping heat – therefore relevant - and they show a pattern which is if I want to trap a significant amount of heat (an amount that I can feel the difference), then the something I use needs to be significant relative to the body I’m trapping heat for and it needs to be contiguous or near contiguous – each and everytime.  Neither of these things apply to the greenhouse gases.

snippet.textDisplay:
Most scientists do not agree we have avoided hot house earth. Indeed recent research has pointed out that the decline in particulates in the atmosphere, partly due to burning less coal and oil, will accelerate global heating. Without further and faster action 4 degrees of heating by 2100 is still a significant probability. And at this level of warming, additional impacts like melting polar ice could further accelerate global heating. Sea water absorbs solar radiation, ice reflects it.

This is a misleading video. It uses selective statistics to mask the continuing rise in emissions. There is a relative reduction in emissions compared to GDP, but we need absolute decoupling of emissions from economic growth and probably degrowth. It does at least point out that we are not moving fast enough. Not nearly fast enough.

I agree we need to avoid hopelessness, there is a better future, but it will be a big change. But we do need people to demand action because apathy also comes from believing that everything is under control and they can carry on as we are. This is currently a bigger issue than hopelesssness!
